sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: Zend_Mail provides generalized functionality to compose and send both text and MIME-compliant multipart e-mail messages. Mail can be sent with Zend_Mail via the php built-in mail() function or via direct SMTP connection.

example.title: Simple E-Mail with Zend_Mail
example.para: A simple e-mail consists of some recipients, a subject, a body and a sender. To send such a mail using the PHP mail() function, do the following:
example.programlisting:
<?php
require_once 'Zend/Mail.php';

$mail = new Zend_Mail();
$mail->setBodyText('This is the text of the mail.');
$mail->setFrom('somebody@example.com', 'Some Sender');
$mail->addTo('somebody_else@example.com', 'Some Recipient');
$mail->setSubject('TestSubject');
$mail->send();

// or alternatively you can use Zend_Mail's fluent interface
require_once 'Zend/Mail.php';

$mail = new Zend_Mail();
$mail->setFrom('somebody@example.com', 'Some Sender')
     ->addTo('somebody_else@example.com', 'Some Recipient')
     ->setSubject('Test Subject')
     ->setBodyText('This is the text of the mail.')
     ->send();
?>

note.title: Minimum definitions
note.para: In order to send an e-mail with Zend_Mail you have to specify at least one recipient, a sender (e.g., with setFrom()), and a message body (text and/or HTML).

sect1.para: For most mail attributes there are "get" methods to read the information stored in the mail object. For further details, please refer to the API documentation. A special one is getRecipients(). It returns an array with all recipient e-mail addresses that were added prior to the method call.
For security reasons, Zend_Mail filters all header fields to prevent header injection with newline (\n) characters.
